introduction.p:
Acceleration and velocity have the same mathematical relation as velocity and position do.
\vec a = \frac{d\vec v}{dt }\ \ \leftrightarrow \ \ \vec v = \frac{d\vec r}{dt }.
Therefore, as in the last section , formally, change in velocity vector will be related to the integration of acceleration over time.
\vec v_f - \vec v_i = \int_{t_i}^{t_f} \vec a(t) dt.
This formal relation can be given more calculational interpretation when we look at the components of this equation.
\amp v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} = \int_{t_i}^{t_f} a_x(t) dt, \amp v_{f,y} - v_{i,y} = \int_{t_i}^{t_f} a_y(t) dt, \amp v_{f,z} - v_{i,z} = \int_{t_i}^{t_f} a_z(t) dt.
The right side of these equations for components, can be computed from plots of corresponding acceleration component versus time by using the "area-under-plot" and "negative-area-over-plot" interpretation of an integral.

example.title: Area under the Acceleration Plot

sidebyside.p:
We can understand Eq. in a plot of a_x vs t as well. Since a_x is constant, the product a_x \Delta t is just the area under the plot of a_x vs t. This gives us following general rule, which also applies to varying a_x.
\Delta v_x \amp = \text{ Area under }a_x\text{ vs } t, \amp = 5\text{ m/s}^2 \times 2\text{ s} = 10 \text{ m/s}.

example.p: If a_x is negative, then this would be area above the plot since a_x=0 line would be above the plot. In this case area will be negative.

The procedure clearly extends to y and z components as well. Once we know the change along different directions, we can combine the components to obtain the magnitude and direction of \Delta \vec v, as usual for vector quantities.

example.title: Velocity from Acceleration - Areas Under Curve

statement.p: below shows acceleration component a_x of a ball at different times. The x component of the velocity of the ball at t = 0 was v_x = 3 \text{ m/s}. Find its v_x at the following instants (a) t = 5\text{ sec}, and (b) t = 10\text{ sec}.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
We will find the change in v_x during t=0 to t=5\text{ sec}. Then we will get v_x at t=5\text{ sec} by adding this change to the v_x at t=0.
v_x(\text{at } t=5\text{ sec}) = v_x(\text{at } t=0) + \Delta v_x,
where
\Delta v_x = \text{Area under the curve of }a_x \text{ between }t=0\text{ and }t=5.
From the plot we find this to give
\Delta v_x = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 5\text{ s} \times 3 \text{ m/s}^2 = 7.5\text{ m/s}.
Therefore,
v_x(\text{at } t=5\text{ sec}) = 3\text{ m/s} + 7.5\text{ m/s} = 10.5\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
We can similarly add to this the area between t=5\text{ sec} and t=10\text{ s} to obtain v_x at 10\text{ s}. Now the \Delta v_x is
\Delta v_x = 5\text{ s}\times (-2\text{ m/s}^2) = -10\text{ m/s}.
Therefore, v_x at t=10\text{ s} is
v_x(\text{at } t=10\text{ s}) = 10.5\text{ m/s} + (-10\text{ m/s}) = 0.5 \text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Velocity of a Box from Area Under Curve Method Applied to Varying Acceleration

statement.p: A box slides on a floor in a straight path such that the magnitude of the acceleration is not constant in time. The data is collected with respect to a Cartesian axis system in which only the a_x is non-zero. The x-component of the acceleration is shown in . As the figure shows, the direction of the acceleration is always pointed towards positive x-axis, but the magnitude varies with time.
(a) Find the velocity of the box at t = 4 sec if it starts out at rest at t = 0.
(b) Find the velocity of the box at t = 10 sec.

hint.p: Area under the curve will give \Delta v_x.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
We work with the duration t = 0 to t = 4\text{ sec}. The area under the curve is just area of a triangle of base 4\text{ sec} and height 3\text{ m/s}^2. Therefore,
v_f = v_i + \Delta v = 0 + \dfrac{1}{2}\times 4\text{ s}\times 3\text{ m/s}^2 = 6\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
We work with the duration t = 0 to t = 10\text{ sec}. The area under the curve is just area of a triangle of base 10\text{ sec} and height 3\text{ m/s}^2. Therefore,
v_f = v_i + \Delta v = 0 + \dfrac{1}{2}\times 10\text{ s}\times 3\text{ m/s}^2 = 15\text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Velocity of a Hockey Puck from Area Under Curve Method Applied to Varying Acceleration

statement.p: A hockey puck is shot on a surface that has different roughness at different places. As a result its acceleration varies from place to place. By placing the x-axis on the line of motion of the puck, we cast the acceleration vector in terms of its x-component which can be plotted with time. Note the acceleration vector cannot be plotted, since they are not ordinary functions; only the components can be plotted. The resulting x-component of the acceleration is shown . The y and z-components of the acceleration are zero. The puck has a velocity at t = 5 sec of 2 m/s towards the positive x axis. Find the initial velocity of the puck at t = 0.

hint.p: Area under the curve will give \Delta v_x.

solution.p: The areas we need are shaded in . The area will be negative here.

I found the area to be
\Delta v \amp = -4\times 3.5 + (-1 )\times 1.5+ \dfrac{(-6+4) \times 2}{2} + \dfrac{(-4+1)\times 1.5}{2} \amp = -19.75\text{ m/s}.
Therefore,
v_f - v_i = \Delta v,
gives
v_i = v_f - \Delta v = 2\text{ m/s} - ( -19.75\text{ m/s}) = 21.75\text{ m/s}.
